item.title: Memory of a handshake
item.description: THERE are moments in a person’s life that are neither formal events nor recorded chapters of history, yet they settle permanently in the hidden chambers of memory. No rush of life, no current of time, no accumulation of experiences can erase them. Rather, as the years pass, these memories become even more luminous, like a distant light suddenly piercing through the......

item.title: Politics of mob terror
item.description: Mob violence has shattered public peace, leaving citizens in an enduring fear. The convergence of mobs, religious extremism and state inaction has let such brutality flourish unchecked. Mob violence and fascism are not random or spontaneous events. They are, rather, deliberate strategies of power, built on the construction of ‘enemies,’ the manipulation of collective......

item.title: Turning dignity into policy
item.description: WHEN Begum Khaleda Zia died on December 30, 2025, Bangladesh did not only lose a former prime minister; it lost a presence that many women had quietly carried with them for decades. She was not born into a political dynasty, nor did she enter public life as a polished insider trained for power. Her political journey emerged from the upheavals of Bangladesh’s......

item.title: No formal mechanism to address e-waste challenge
item.description: A RAPID surge in electronic waste, or e-waste, generation, coupled with the absence of a formal mechanism for its management, is concerning. A Transparency International Bangladesh study says that about 72 per cent of users keep or dump unused or expired electronic goods at home while 88 per cent are unaware of proper e-waste management. The study says that......
